title: ［法律界］唔知咩人出咗個聲明比所有香港事務律師

replies.msg:
法律界痛心疾首的一天

各位法律界人士:

看到昨天在銅鑼灣發生的一連串暴力行為，我們感到十分痛心。這一連串的暴力據說源於香港即將建立一套健全維護國家安全的法律制度和執行機制。無論原因是什麼，這些暴力行為是絕對不可以接受的。

從新聞得知法律界其中一員亦受到無理的猛烈暴力襲擊。不論動機或政治原因如何，這種無理的暴力襲擊是絕對不可接受的。

我們在此想問以下幾位曾經過往對無理暴力表示同情的法律界的人仕，包括律師會理事#張達明，法律界立法會議員#郭榮鏗、#陳淑莊、#楊岳橋及公眾人物#戴耀廷、#梁家傑：

1. 你是否同意暴力是不能解決香港現有問題？特別是法律界的一員被猛烈暴力襲擊留院是絕對不可接受的？

2. 對於公眾有影響力的人士，請問你們是否覺得有責任不要鼓吹公眾以犯罪及以暴力襲擊不同政見的人士？在此我們特別留意到：梁家傑先生早前說的「暴力有時是解決問題的方法」，楊岳橋先生說的「案底令人生更精彩」，戴耀廷先生所說的「犯法就要受到制裁是守舊的觀念」！

另外我們留意到聲稱「獨立及開明聲音」的2020年律師會理事會選舉五位候選人發出的聲明，他們一方面表示對暴力行為的關注，另一方面卻把昨天的恐怖暴力視為和平集會。尤其是他們把單方面襲擊律師的行為形容為雙向挑釁。

我們特別想指出昨天的集會是沒有得到警方批准的，昨天的大部份集會，特別是在銅鑼灣發生的一切不單止構成「公安條例」下的非法集會及暴動，而且違反了「預防及控制疾病（禁止群組聚集）規例」下的八人限聚要求。

在此我們要求以上五位律師會理事候選人：
A) 毫無保留地收回他們對於昨日的集會列為和平集會的言論及把單向集擊形容為雙向爭吵的言論；

B) 就他們錯誤的言論誤導公眾以為這些集會是合法的，及故意把這些暴力行為的法律後果淡化，向公眾道歉。

我們在此清楚地指出:

1.如果你們拒絕作出以上兩點聲明；及

2. 拒絕與不認同以上兩個大原則的人割蓆；及

3. 五位律師會理事會參選人拒絕收回他們把昨天的集會定為和平集會及把單向暴力襲擊形容為爭吵的不正當聲明及向公眾道歉，

你們將被視為為了謀取政治利益，而背棄你們在法庭所作出的守護及捍衛法治的誓言，你們將會被視為毁滅香港的罪魁禍首！

一班睇到眼火爆嘅無黨無派律師

2020年5月25日

A Heartbreaking Day for the Legal Profession

Dear colleagues

It is with heavy hearts that we watched live news regarding the latest round of violence unfolding in Causeway Bay. This latest outrage was perpetrated ostensibly as a response to the news that a regime of law and enforcement protecting national security would be set up in Hong Kong. Regardless of the reason, this is plainly not acceptable.

In particular, we refer to the news that one of our fellow legal professionals has been subject to a savage and unjustifiable attack. Regardless of creed or political views, such action is indefensible.

We take this opportunity to pose the following questions to those who represent the legal profession in the Law Society #Eric Cheung, and the Legislative Council #Dennis Kwok, #Tanya Chan, #Alvin Yeung, as well as those who hold outsized influence with the public #Benny Tai, #Alan Leong who have through their past conduct or words, demonstrated sympathy for such unwarranted violence.

1. Do you agree that violence is not an acceptable solution to the current situation in Hong Kong: specifically that it is unacceptable for a member of the legal profession to be attacked so viciously that he ended up in hospital?

2. Do you agree that those who are in positions of influence have the responsibility to ensure their public comments do not encourage crimes or violence against those who do not hold the same views? We refer specifically to statements such as:
- “violence can sometimes be a solution to problems” made by Mr Alan Leong;

- “criminal records can make life more interesting” made by Legco member Mr Alvin Yeung; and
- the commentary that “if one breaks the law, one ought to be punished” is an outdated and obsolete concept, as made by Mr Benny Tai.

We also note that the 5 candidates for the 2020 Law Society Council election who call themselves “Independent and Firm Voices” have issued a statement in respect of this incident. In this statement, they expressed concern regarding “violence against individuals” but at the same time described the perpetrators of the massive scale of violence as “peaceful protestors”. In particular, the characterisation that a one-way attack on a fellow legal professional was actually the result of a two-sided “altercation”.

We would like to put on record that consent for yesterday's mass gatherings was not obtained from the police, and that most of the gathering and in particular the one at Causeway Bay constituted unlawful assembly and rioting under the Public Order Ordinance, and were in breach of the prohibition against gathering of over 8 people under the Prevention and Control of Disease (Prohibition on Group Gathering) Regulation.

We demand that these 5 candidates:

(A) withdraw their wrongful characterization of those who participated in any part of Sunday's unlawful activities as “peaceful protestors” and the wrongful attribution of the one-sided attack to a mere “altercation”;

and

(B) apologize to the public for their obfuscation on the illegality of the gathering as well as downplaying the culpability of the perpetrators of the violence.

Let us be clear([tag everyone]):

I. any answer to the negative in respect of questions 1 & 2 above,

II. any refusal to cut ties with those who reject the above principles, and

III. in relation to the 5 “Independent and Firm Voices” candidates, any refusal to withdraw their mischaracterisation and wrongful attribution and apologize to the public in line with demand (A) & (B) above,

would be interpreted rightly as an abandonment of one of our own, as a dereliction of your sworn duty to fairly uphold and defend the Rule of Law and as the cheap partisan politicisation of a calamity that is befalling Hong Kong.

A group of furious lawyers
